Connectivity Timeline in Canada

When Did the Problem Start, and What Upgrades Have Occurred?

When Did Connectivity Issues Begin?

Connectivity issues in Canada have roots in the countryâ€™s vast geography and the challenges of building infrastructure in rural and remote areas. Early internet adoption in urban centers during the 1990s left rural areas lagging behind, creating a digital divide that persists today.

Timeline of Technological Upgrades

1995: Early Internet Rollout

Canada begins widespread adoption of dial-up internet in urban areas, but rural regions remain underserved.

2000s: DSL and Cable Internet

Faster internet technologies like DSL and cable become common in cities, but rural areas still depend on dial-up or costly satellite connections.

2010: Broadband Expansion

The Canadian government launches initiatives to improve broadband access, including subsidies for rural infrastructure projects.

2015: 4G LTE Network Rollout

Cellular providers expand 4G LTE coverage across major population centers, but rural areas still experience patchy service.

2020: 5G Rollout Begins

Canada starts deploying 5G networks in urban areas, promising faster speeds and lower latency, but rural adoption remains slow.

2022: High-Speed Internet Access Program

The federal government announces significant funding to connect 98% of Canadians to high-speed internet by 2026.
